front.title: Simple Cloud Identity Management: Core Schema 1.0 - draft 1

abstract.t: The Simple Cloud Identity Management (SCIM) specification is designed to make managing user identity in cloud based applications and services easier. The specification suite seeks to build upon experience with existing schemas and deployments, placing specific emphasis on simplicity of development and integration, while applying existing authentication, authorization, and privacy models. It's intent is to reduce the cost and complexity of user management operations by providing a common user schema and extension model, as well as binding documents to provide patterns for exchanging this schema using standard protocols. In essence, make it fast, cheap, and easy to move users in to, out of, and around the cloud.

This document provides a platform neutral schema and extension model for representing users and groups. This schemas is intended for exchange and use with cloud service providers. Standard serializations of that schema using JSON and XML are also provided.

section.title: Requirements Notation and Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .
Throughout this document, values are quoted to indicate that they are to be taken literally. When using these values in protocol messages, the quotes MUST NOT be used as part of the value.

section.title: Overview
section.t: While there are existing standards for describing and exchanging user information, many of these standards can be difficult to implement and/or use wire protocols that do not easily traverse firewalls nor easily layer onto existing web protocols. As a result, many cloud providers provide their own non-standard APIs for managing users within their services. This increases both the cost and complexity associated with organizations adopting products and services from multiple cloud providers as they must perform redundant integration development. Similarly, cloud services providers seeking to interoperate with multiple application marketplaces or cloud identity providers must be redundantly integrated.

SCIM seeks to simplify this problem through a simple to implement specification suite that provides a common user schema and extension model, as well as binding documents to provide patterns for exchanging this schema using standard protocols. It draws inspiration and best practice, building upon existing user APIs and schemas from a wide variety of sources including, but not limited to, existing APIs exposed by cloud providers, PortableContacts, and LDAP directory services.

This document provides a platform neutral schema and extension model for representing users and groups. This schemas is intended for exchange and use with cloud service providers.Standard serializations of that schema using JSON and XML are also provided. Additional binding documents provide a standard REST API, as well as use of SCIM schema over federation protocols such as SAML and OpenID

section.title: SCIM Schema Structure
section.t: SCIM schema provides a minimal core schema for representing users and groups, encompassing common attributes found in many existing deployments and schemas.

Each attribute is defined as either a Singular Attribute, in which case there MUST NOT be more than one instance of that field per user, or as a Plural Attribute, in which case any number of instances of that attribute MAY be present per user. The only exception to this is a "schemas" attribute used in representations that lack native support for expressing schemas such as JSON. This attribute allows introspection of the supported schema version for a SCIM representation as well any schema extensions supported by that representation. The 'schemas' attribute is an array of strings, and values must by URNs designated by the corresponding schema definition.

SCIM information is formatted using labeled attributes with either structured or unstructured string data. Unless otherwise specified, all attributes are optional and of type xs:string. All encoding MUST be UTF-8. Each attribute label uses camelCase notation. Unless specified, all attribute values MUST NOT contain any newline characters (\r or \n).
Each attribute value consists of one of the following types:

list.t: A single string attribute which MAY specify a REQUIRED data format or allow any string. A simple attribute MAY contain Canonical Values specified, in which case Service Providers SHOULD try to conform to those values if appropriate, but MAY provide alternate string values to represent additional values.

A multi-value attribute containing any combination of other attributes. Complex attributes are defined by listing the child attributes and their types. For most Complex Attributes, the value sub-attribute contains the Major Value of that attribute (i.e. the primary piece of information described by that attribute), and the other attributes provide additional meta-data.
A special case of a Simple Attribute with two legal values: true and false. Values are case-sensitive.

The attribute value MUST be a valid xsd:dateTime (e.g. 2008-01-23T04:56:22Z) values as specified in
section 3.2.7 of the XML Schema Datatypes Specification. .

The attribute value MUST be encoded as a valid xsd:base64Binary value as specified in section 3.2.16 of the XML Schema Datatypes Specification.. No binary attributes are specified in the core schema, however, extended schemas may opt to include images, digital signatures and the like.

section.t: Plural Attributes allow for lists of attributes using a special complex type. All Plural Attributes, unless otherwise specified, have the same three standard sub-attributes:

The primary value of this attribute, e.g. the actual e-mail address, phone number, id, URL, etc. Each non-empty Plural Attribute value MUST contain at least the value sub-attribute, but all other sub-attributes are optional. REQUIRED.
The type of attribute for this instance, usually used to label the preferred function of the given resource. OPTIONAL
A Boolean value indicating whether this instance of the Plural Attribute is the primary or preferred value of for this attribute, e.g. the preferred mailing address or primary e-mail address. Service Providers MUST NOT mark more than one instance of the same Plural Attribute as primary, and MAY choose not to mark any attributes as primary, if this information is not available. For efficiency, Service Providers SHOULD NOT mark all non-primary attributes with primary="false", but should instead omit this sub-attribute for all non-primary instances. OPTIONAL
A human readable name, primarily used for display purposes where the value is an iopaque or complex type such as an id. OPTIONAL When returning Plural Attributes, Service Providers SHOULD canonicalize the value returned, if appropriate (e.g. for e-mail addresses and URLs). Providers MAY return the same value more than once with different types (e.g. the same e-mail address may used for work and home), but SHOULD NOT return the same (type, value) combination more than once per Plural Attribute, as this complicates processing by the Consumer.

section.title: Schema Extension Model
section.t: SCIM schema follows an object extension model similar to ObjectClasses used in LDAP. Unlike LDAP there is no inheritance model; all extensions additive. ( similar to auxiliary objectClasses ) Each value indicates additive schema that may exist in a SCIM representation as specified by extensions not defined in this suite. Each schema extension must identify a canonical URI used to identify the extension. Schema Extensions MUST follow the rules of singular and plural attribute structured defined in this core schema specification. Schema extensions MUST NOT override or redefine any schema defined in this core specification. For representations that support expressing schema, the native convention MUST be used (For instance, XML Namespace). When the the 'schemas' attribute is being used ( as defined in Section N), additional URIs MUST be specified in the 'schemas' attribute array.

section.title: Common Schema Attributes
section.t: Each resource represented by SCIM (Users, Groups, etc.) implicitly includes the following common attributes. These common attributes MUST be included in all SCIM resources, including any new resource types that may be defined. It it not necessary to designate support for Core Schema with a value in the "schemas" attributes ( defined in the next section ), as inclusion is implicit and mandatory

list.t: Unique identifier for the SCIM resource as defined by the Service Provider. Each representation of the resource MUST include a non-empty id value. This identifier MUST be unique across the Service Provider's entire set of resources. It MUST be a stable, non-reassignable identifier that does not change when the same resource is returned in subsequent requests. The value of the id attribute is always issued by the Service Provider and MUST never be specified by the Service Consumer. REQUIRED.

A complex type containing metadata about the resource. OPTIONAL. The DateTime the User was first added to the Service Provider. The attribute MUST be a DateTime. OPTIONAL.
The most recent DateTime the details of this User were updated at the Service Provider. If this User has never been modified since its initial creation, the value MUST be the same as the value of created. The attribute MUST be a DateTime. OPTIONAL.

section.title: "schemas" Attribute
section.t: SCIM supports resources of different types, with extensible schemas. Each resources and/or extension must indicate using fully qualified URIs

Where a specific representation has existing support for expressing schema, the traditional convention of that representation MUST be applied. For example, when representing users using XML, XML Namespace should be used.
When a representation does not explicitly provide support for indicating a schema, such as JSON, a 'schemas' attribute is used to indicate the version of SCIM schema as well as any schema extensions.

list.t: The schemas attribute is an array of strings which allows introspection of the supported schema version for a SCIM representation as well any schema extensions supported by that representation. Each string value must be a unique URN. This specification defines URNs for User, Group, and some standard extensions. All representations of SCIM schema MUST include a non-zero value array with value(s) of the URNs supported by that representation. Duplicate values MUST NOT be included. Value order is not specified and MUST not impact behavior. REQUIRED.

section.title: SCIM User Schema
section.t: SCIM provides a schema for representing users, identified using the following URN: 'urn:scim:schemas:core:1.0' ( Note: we're currently using an un-registered urn while in draft form). The following attributes are defined in addition to those attributes defined in Core SCIM Schema:

list.t: Unique identifier for the User, typically used by the user to directly authenticate to the service provider. Often displayed to the user as their unique identifier within the system ( as opposed to id or externalId, which are generally opaque and not user-friendly identifiers ) Each User MUST include a non-empty userName value. This identifier MUST be unique across the Service Consumer's entire set of Users. It MUST be a stable ID that does not change when the same user is returned in subsequent requests. REQUIRED.

Unique identifier for the User as defined by the Service Consumer. The externalId may simplify identification of the User between Service Consumer and Service provider by allowing the consumer to refer to the User with it's own identifier, obviating the need to store a local mapping between the local identifier of the user and the identifier used by the Service Provider. Each User MAY include a non-empty externalId value. The value of the externalId attribute is always issued be the Service Consumer and can never be specified by the Service Provider. This identifier MUST be unique across the Service Consumer's entire set of Users. It MUST be a stable, non-reassignable identifier that does not change when the same user is returned in subsequent requests. The Service Provider MUST always interpret the externalId as scoped to the Service Consumer's tenant. OPTIONAL.

The components of the user's real name. Providers MAY return just the full name as a single string in the formatted sub-attribute, or they MAY return just the individual component attributes using the other sub-attributes, or they MAY return both. If both variants are returned, they SHOULD be describing the same name, with the formatted name indicating how the component attributes should be combined. OPTIONAL. The full name, including all middle names, titles, and suffixes as appropriate, formatted for display (e.g. Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.
The family name of the User, or "Last Name" in most Western languages (e.g. Jensen given the full name Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.
The given name of the User, or "First Name" in most Western languages (e.g. Barbara given the full name Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.
The middle name(s) of the User (e.g. Robert given the full name Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.
The honorific prefix(es) of the User, or "Title" in most Western languages (e.g. Ms. given the full name Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.
The honorifix suffix(es) of the User, or "Suffix" in most Western languages (e.g. III. given the full name Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III.). OPTIONAL.

The name of the User, suitable for display to end-users. Each User returned MAY include a non-empty displayName value. The name SHOULD be the full name of the User being described if known (e.g. Babs Jensen or Ms. Barbara J Jensen, III), but MAY be a username or handle, if that is all that is available (e.g. bjensen). The value provided SHOULD be the primary textual label by which this User is normally displayed by the Service Provider when presenting it to end-users. OPTIONAL
The casual way to address the user in real life, e.g. "Bob" or "Bobby" instead of "Robert". This attribute SHOULD NOT be used to represent a user's username (e.g. bjensen or mpepperidge). OPTIONAL.
URL to a page representing the user's online profile. OPTIONAL.
The user’s title, such as “Vice President.” OPTIONAL.
Used to identify the organization to user relationship. Typical values used might be "Contractor", "Employee", "Intern", "Temp", "External", and "Unknown" but any value may be used. OPTIONAL.
Used to indicate an individual's preferred written or spoken language. Generally used for localizing the interface presented to the user. OPTIONAL. TODO - what ISO code list should we use here?

Used to indicate the user's default location for purposes of localizing items such as currency, date time format, numerical representations, etc. OPTIONAL. TODO - what ISO code list should we use here?
The User's time zone in the public-domain time zone database format; e.g.,'America/Denver'. Valid values and details at http://cs.ucla.edu/~eggert/tz/tz-link.htm . OPTIONAL.

section.title: Plural Attributes
section.t: The following plural attributes are defined:

list.t: E-mail addresses for the user. The value SHOULD be canonicalized by the Service Provider, e.g. bjensen@example.com instead of bjensen@EXAMPLE.COM. Canonical Type values of work, home, and other. OPTIONAL.
Phone numbers for the user. No canonical value is assumed here. Canonical Type values of work, home, mobile, fax, pager and other. OPTIONAL.

Instant messaging address for the user. No official canonicalization rules exist for all instant messaging addresses, but Service Providers SHOULD remove all whitespace and convert the address to lowercase, if this is appropriate for the service this IM address is used for. Instead of the standard Canonical Values for type, this attribute defines the following Canonical Values to represent currently popular IM services: aim, gtalk, icq, xmpp, msn, skype, qq, and yahoo. OPTIONAL.

URL of a photo of the user. The value SHOULD be a canonicalized URL, and MUST point to an actual image file (e.g. a GIF, JPEG, or PNG image file) rather than to a web page containing an image. Service Providers MAY return the same image at different sizes, though it is recognized that no standard for describing images of various sizes currently exists. Note that this attribute SHOULD NOT be used to send down arbitrary photos taken by this user, but specifically profile photos of the user suitable for display when describing the user. Instead of the standard Canonical Values for type, this attribute defines the following Canonical Values to represent popular photo sizes: photo, thumbnail. OPTIONAL.

A physical mailing address for this User, as described in (address Element). Canonical Type Values of work, home, and other. The value attribute is a complex type with the following sub-attributes. OPTIONAL The full mailing address, formatted for display or use with a mailing label. This attribute MAY contain newlines. OPTIONAL
The full street address component, which may include house number, street name, PO BOX, and multi-line extended street address information. This attribute MAY contain newlines. OPTIONAL
The city or locality component. OPTIONAL
The state or region component. OPTIONAL
The zipcode or postal code component. OPTIONAL
The country name component. OPTIONAL. TODO what ISO code list should we use here?

A list of groups that the user belongs to. The values are meant to enable expression of common group or role based access control models, although no explicit authorization model is defined. It is intended that the semantics of group membership and any behavior or authorization granted as a result of membership are defined by the Service Provider are considered out of scope for this specification. This value has NO canonical types and removes the standard canonical types. If the SCIM Service Provider exposes a Group resource, the value MUST be the "id" attribute of the corresponding Group resources to which the user belongs. TODO - do we need to provider a human readable name here? OPTIONAL.

A list of entitlements for the User that represent a thing the User has. That is, an entitlement is an additional right to a thing, object or service. No vocabulary or syntax is specified and Service Providers/Consumers are expected to encode sufficient information in the value so as to accurately and without ambiguity determine what the User has access to. This value has NO canonical types though type may be useful as a means to scope entitlements. OPTIONAL.

A list of roles for the User that collectively represent who the User is; e.g., 'Student', "Faculty". No vocabulary or syntax is specified though it is expected that a role value is a string or label representing a collection of entitlements. This value has NO canonical types and removes the standard canonical types. OPTIONAL.

section.title: SCIM Enterprise User Schema Extension
section.t: The following SCIM extension defines attributes commonly used in representing users that belong to, or act on behalf of a business or enterprise. The enterprise user extention is identified using the following URI: 'urn:scim:schemas:extension:user:enterprise:1.0' ( Note: we're currently using an un-registered urn while in draft form).
The following Singular Attributes are defined:

list.t: Numeric or alphanumeric identifier assigned to a person, typically based on order of hire or association with an organization. Single valued. OPTIONAL.
Identifies the name of a cost center. OPTIONAL.
Identifies the name of an organization. OPTIONAL.
Identifies the name of a division. OPTIONAL.
Identifies the name of a department. OPTIONAL.

The user's manager. A complex type that optionally allows Service Providers to represent organizational hierarchy by referencing the "id" attribute of another user. OPTIONAL The id of the SCIM resource representing the User's manager. OPTIONAL.
The displayName of the User's manager. OPTIONAL.

section.title: SCIM Group Schema
section.t: SCIM provides a schema for representing groups, identified using the following URN: 'urn:scim:schemas:core:1.0' ( Note: we're currently using an un-registered urn while in draft form).

Group resources are meant to enable expression of common group or role based access control models, although no explicit authorization model is defined. It is intended that the semantics of group membership and any behavior or authorization granted as a result of membership are defined by the Service Provider and considered out of scope for this specification.
The following Singular Attribute is defined in addition to the common attributes defined in SCIM Core Schema: A human readable name for the group. OPTIONAL.

The following Plural Attribute is defined in addition to the common attributes defined in SCIM Core Schema: A list of members of the group. Canonical Type "user" and "group". The value must be the "id" of a SCIM resource, either a user, or a group. The intention of the group type is to allow the Service Provider to support nested groups. REQUIRED.
